content:
The Act may be cited as the "Beginning Farmers Agenda Act of 2016" and includes a table of contents outlining improved access to land. The "Beginning Farmers Agenda Act of 2016" includes provisions for land trust eligibility, priority for agricultural land easements, exclusion of gain from farm sales, prequalification for Farm Service Agency programs, increased farm ownership loan limits, minimum funding for easements, and improved access to Department of Agriculture training and programs. The "Beginning Farmers Agenda Act of 2016" includes provisions for coordination, transfer of Advisory Committee, online customer self-service portal, extension of development program, mandatory funding for individual development accounts pilot program, and sale of surplus farm equipment to disadvantaged farmers, veterans, and beginning farmers. The "Beginning Farmers Agenda Act of 2016" includes provisions for mandatory funding for farmers' market and local food promotion program, grants for farm viability programs, and land trust eligibility for assistance for agricultural land easements. The "Beginning Farmers Agenda Act of 2016" includes provisions for land trust eligibility for assistance in reserving agricultural land easements. The Act of 1985 is amended to include provisions for land trust eligibility for assistance in reserving agricultural land easements. SEC. 102 amends the Food Security Act of 1985 to prioritize the option to purchase agricultural land easements at agricultural value. SEC. 103 excludes gain from the sale of a farm or ranch to a qualified agricultural purchaser. SEC. 139F. GAIN FROM SALE OF FARM OR RANCH TO A QUALIFIED AGRICULTURAL PURCHASER. SEC. 139F exempts gain from the sale of property used in a farming business to a qualified agricultural purchaser from gross income, provided certain conditions are met, including ownership and usage requirements, buyer qualifications, acreage limitations, and perpetual use restrictions. The gain excluded from gross income under SEC. 139F for the sale of property used in a farming business is limited to $250,000, or $500,000 for joint returns if ownership and usage requirements are met by both spouses. A qualified agricultural purchaser is defined as an individual meeting specific criteria. A purchaser is defined as an individual who is a beginning farmer or rancher, socially disadvantaged farmer, or veteran farmer or rancher. A beginning farmer or rancher is someone who has not operated a farm for more than 10 consecutive years. The text chunk discusses the criteria for material and substantial participation in the operation of a farm or ranch, which includes providing substantial day-to-day labor and management. This is relevant for individuals or entities seeking eligibility as purchasers under specific categories like beginning farmers or socially disadvantaged farmers. The text chunk outlines the criteria for material and substantial participation in farm or ranch operations, emphasizing the need for active involvement in day-to-day activities to ensure smooth operation. It also references applicable rules similar to those in section 121(d). "Sec. 139F. Gain from sale of farm or ranch to a qualified agricultural purchaser. Effective Date: The amendments apply to sales and exchanges after the enactment date. SEC. 104. Prequalification of prospective applicants for credit from Farm Service Agency programs." The Secretary of Agriculture must develop procedures by October 1, 2016, for the Farm Service Agency to provide preliminary determinations to loan applicants regarding credit qualification. Additionally, there is an increase in the limitation on the amount of direct farm ownership loans and indexation of the limit to inflation. Section 305 of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act is amended to increase the loan amount to $500,000, adjusted for inflation. Section 1265D of the Food Security Act is amended to ensure that at least 40% of funds are used for agricultural land and wetland reserve easements. Additionally, a report on the Agricultural Conservation Easement Program is required. The Chief of the Natural Resources Conservation Service must submit a report on the Agricultural Conservation Easement Program to the House and Senate Committees on Agriculture within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will evaluate how the program supports beginning farmers and ranchers in purchasing land. Additionally, there is a provision for improved access to Department of Agriculture training and programs for beginning farmers. SEC. 201. Beginning farmer coordination program established to promote communication and increase access to programs and land for beginning farmers. SEC. 202. Advisory committee on beginning farmers and ranchers transferred to Farm Service Agency jurisdiction. The Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994 is amended to coordinate activities with the Advisory Committee on Beginning Farmers and Ranchers. Additionally, a Department of Agriculture online customer self-service portal is established. The Department of Agriculture will develop an online customer self-service portal for farmers and ranchers to access program information and complete applications. Congress emphasizes that the portal should not disadvantage those without high-speed internet. $6,000,000 is authorized for the project over a three-year period starting in 2016. SEC. 204 extends the Beginning Farmer and Rancher Development Program until 2021. SEC. 205 mandates funding for the Beginning Farmer and Rancher Individual Development Accounts Pilot Program. Section 333B of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act is amended to allocate $5,000,000 annually from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds for fiscal year 2017 and beyond. Additionally, Section 206 allows for the sale of surplus farm equipment or property to socially disadvantaged farmers, veteran farmers, and beginning farmers. The Administrator of General Services can sell surplus farm equipment to socially disadvantaged farmers, veteran farmers, or beginning farmers who are actively involved in farming operations. A beginning farmer is defined as someone who has not operated a farm for more than 10 consecutive years. The terms "socially disadvantaged farmer or rancher" and "veteran farmer or rancher" are defined in the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990. TITLE III--INVESTMENT IN LOCAL AND REGIONAL FOOD SYSTEMS

SEC. 301. MANDATORY FUNDING FOR FARMERS' MARKET AND LOCAL FOOD PROMOTION PROGRAM. Amends the Farmer-to-Consumer Direct Marketing Act to allocate $40,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2017 to 2021.

SEC. 302. GRANTS TO SUPPORT FARM VIABILITY PROGRAMS. SEC. 302. Grants authorized by the Secretary of Agriculture to support farm viability programs aim to improve economic viability and environmental integrity of farms through farm viability plans. Assistance includes environmental, technical, and business planning to modernize agricultural operations and aid in land access and transfer. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2017-2021.
